comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content: Most of the open area now under the railway, of course. At least the beautiful, little Cusoms House has survived.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
From the toast-rack trams, cars, and clothes, I would say 1920s.

Interesting to compare with a recently added Powerhouse Museum Collection photo of almost the same view in 1902.  Wharves, tram pylons, Belmore Hotel etc rebuilt.  And electric street lamps (1904).   Circular Quay has always been a place of change, except Wardie44B's Customs House (much altered over time) and oddly, the Paragon Hotel manages to avoid developers.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/4903285467/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I wonder about the large number of people going to and from the ferry wharves at noon (Customs House clock).  Was it a half-day holiday or a Saturday?

comment.author: 29029178@N03
comment._content:
I would place the photo as the mid  1920's, The city rly eastern side is still being built. It opened in 1926. The connection between St James and Wynyard is still a couple of decades off. There are no corridor trams in the photo, and these were introduced in the mid 1930's. Plus the rebuilding of Circular Quay wharves had not taken place.

Note O, L/P and E cls trams

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
Thanks for your comments everyone, we've added the date c.1920s above.

AB

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: It is the mid-20's, and is taken almost exactly on the alignment of the future railway viaduct, the northern piles of which were actually in the water's edge (wharf shed buildings in this picture). The entrance to the railway tunnel was used as an air raid shelter during WWII and was sign-posted as such.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/63385174@N06] Thanks for your comment; that is interesting to know about the railway tunnel being used as a WWII air raid shelter. 

AB
